You don’t have to do nodal analysis at all at that 4:06 , just do a quick source transformation for the Voltage source putting an upward facing current source of 50/4 Amps parallel to a 4Ohm resistor. After that Add the 50/4 and the 3Amp current source as they’re both in parallel whilst also adding the parallel 5 ohm , 4 ohm resistors. Then just do V=IR which results in 31/2 times 20/9 = 34.4V .

It makes 11.2(R Thevenin) + 6 (R Load) = 17.2 ohms. Thus we can divide 34.4V(V Thevenin) with 17.2 ohms in order to easily calculate the ampere that passes through the load with the help of Thevenin Equivalent of the circuit.

the formula for calculating equivalent resistance when resistors are in parallel is 1/R = 1/R1 + 1/R2 so  1/R would be = 1/4 + 1/5 1/R = 9/20  therefore R would be  20/9 = 2.22   since we're taking reciprocal of 9/20 - it's easier to write (9/20)^-1  as it means the same thing as 20/9   and then 9 is added to 2.2 which gives us 11.2

there's no current flowing over the 9 ohm resistor because there's an infinite resistance across point A and B due to the presence of air in between the two points ( since air acts as an insulator) so current is negligible, almost zero.
for the Thévenin circuit we remove the load resistor

To find the Thevenin Voltage, we have to assume the load resistor to be an open circuit because that's the variable that we want to measure. i.e. The current across the load. The will be no current flowing through the 9 ohm resistor since there is an open circuit across the path A to B and so all of the current will be flowing through the 5 ohm resistor. There will be no path along an open circuit

Great question! It takes a bit of thought to see how it works but really it is parallel the whole time, its just that in the given diagram, the 4 ohm resistor is drawn at the top of that loop instead of on the left side so the resistors don't "look" parallel. All he's doing is scootching that 4 ohm resistor to the left down the wire, which of course doesn't change anything about how the circuit works. He could extend that wire in a crazy zig-zag mess and put the 4 ohm resistor anywhere along it but based on where the nodes are, the resistors are still connected in parallel. Does that help?

nope, actually, the thevenin's resistance was the sum of all resistance, except for the load resistance, in order to simplify the circuit to a series circuit. in another way, you have not included all resistance. when calculating the current, you have to subs the R load in the circuit, then add it with thevenin resistance in order to get the total resistance of the circuit, which is now a series circuit. That's why you still have to add Rth with R load to get the correct value of current in the circuit.

@wankhairolyusri9449  its just that he simplified the numbers. Added up the vc to -9 and moved it to the other side, so it becomes positive. And added up 250 to 60, thus giving you 310

See, the circuit actually has a load resistance (call it RL). This RL is always changing so it can be considered taken out till we calculate the equivalent resistance of the remaining resistors which have a fixed value. So only for the sake of calculating all the known values, RL has been taken out and A and B become open. Otherwise, in reality, A and B are closed and since there is no source between A and C, and A and B-- so no potential drop across AC branch, hence the value of Va = Vc. Hope you understood.

@bryyd1922  the value of RL can literally be anything. Thevenin Equivalent looks at what voltage that resistor sees in front of it and the current across it. The voltage drop, in this case is 12, will change with any RL values since the VL=RL*iL and we calculated iL using the thevenin equvalent of the circuit.   For example, if you plug in 1 ohm as RL, you will get these values: iL = 2.8197 A VA = iL * RL = 2.8197A * 1Ohm =  2.8197 V VC = 2.8197V + 2.8197A * 9Ohm = 28.197 V Current across 5 Ohm = 28.197V / 5ohm = 5.6394 A = i5 <--- this is just a random variable i chose Current across point C, iC = i5 + iL = 5.6394a + 2.8197A = 8.4591A Current across 4 Ohm, i4 = iC - 3 = 5.4591A = i4  <----- Again, another variable to denote the current across 4 ohm  Voltage drop at 4 ohm = 4Ohm * i4 = 4 * 5.4591 = 21.8364 V = V4 <----- variable for voltage drop across 4 ohm And in the end, going back to the power source, VC + V4 = 50.0V <---- 50V at the source which is always a good way to check if youre doing your calculation correctly.

You say the RL can literally be anything but what if we just use 1000 ohms? then the problem wouldn't make any sense meaning you can't just throw any RL in and expect the same results. thevanin resistance equivalent was found to be 11.2ohms. What  is VL? what is iL? how were those figured out?

@thenatmann1  I don't know where you found a statement where I said that you can "expect the same results" by throwing any RL values. You don't. You get a different Isc and Voc every time and that is what you use to find Isc = ILoad which is the current through the load resistor. The voltage drop in the load is VL and is calculated using RL and IL, obviously, is different from every load resistor. If you have R = 0, then your IL=Isc would be infinite as R=0 is technically a short. If R = infinity, then Isc is open and is equal to 0. Using Isc and RL, you can find the voltage drop across the load (6 ohms), which is 12V in this case.
